notes.title: Introduction to Real Numbers
points: Real numbers include all rational and irrational numbers
Number line represents all real numbers
Every point on the number line corresponds to a unique real number

formulas.title: Absolute Value
formulas.formula: |a| = a if a ≥ 0, -a if a < 0
formulas.explanation: The absolute value represents the distance of a number from zero on the number line

realworld.title: Temperature Scales
realworld.description: Understanding negative temperatures in weather forecasting using absolute values

notes.title: Understanding Rational Numbers
points: Numbers that can be expressed as p/q where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0
Terminating and recurring decimals are rational

notes.title: Understanding Irrational Numbers
points: Numbers that cannot be expressed as simple fractions

formulas.title: Pythagorean Theorem
formulas.formula: a² + b² = c²
formulas.explanation: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of squares of other two sides

realworld.title: Construction and Architecture
realworld.description: Using √2 in diagonal measurements of square rooms or buildings

notes.title: Types of Decimal Expansions
points: Terminating decimals: Have finite number of digits after decimal
Non-terminating repeating: Have infinite repeating digits after decimal
Non-terminating non-repeating: Have infinite non-repeating digits

formulas.title: Converting Recurring Decimal to Fraction
formulas.formula: x = 0.abcabc... then 1000x = abc.abcabc...
formulas.explanation: Subtract the first equation from the second to eliminate the repeating part

realworld.title: Financial Calculations
realworld.description: Understanding recurring decimals in interest rate calculations

formulas.title: Exponent Rules
formulas.formula: (a/b)⁻ⁿ = (b/a)ⁿ
formulas.explanation: Negative exponents in fractions can be simplified by inverting the fraction

realworld.title: Scientific Notation
realworld.description: Using exponents to represent distances between planets or sizes of atoms

notes.title: Introduction to Algebraic Expressions
points: Combination of variables and constants using operations (+, -, ×, ÷)
Terms: Parts of expression separated by + or - signs
Coefficient: Numerical factor of a term
Like and Unlike terms: Terms with same variables and powers

notes.title: Types of Expressions
points: Binomial: Expression with two unlike terms (e.g., 2x + 3y)
Trinomial: Expression with three unlike terms (e.g., x² + 2x + 1)
Polynomial: Expression with one or more terms

formulas.title: Addition of Algebraic Expressions
formulas.formula: (a + b) + c = a + (b + c)
formulas.explanation: Associative property of addition for algebraic expressions

formulas.title: Subtraction of Algebraic Expressions
formulas.formula: a - (b + c) = (a - b) - c
formulas.explanation: Distributive property of subtraction over addition

realworld.title: Shopping Budget
realworld.description: Calculating total cost when buying multiple items with different prices and quantities

notes.title: Introduction to Polynomials
points: Expression with variables and coefficients using operations (+, -, ×)
Degree: Highest power of the variable
Standard form: Terms written in descending order of their degrees
Zero polynomial: All coefficients are zero

formulas.title: Remainder Theorem
formulas.formula: If p(x) is divided by (x - a), remainder is p(a)
formulas.explanation: Helps find remainder without actual division

formulas.title: Factor Theorem
formulas.formula: (x - a) is a factor of p(x) if p(a) = 0
formulas.explanation: Determines if (x - a) is a factor of given polynomial

realworld.title: Projectile Motion
realworld.description: Quadratic polynomials model the trajectory of a thrown ball

notes.title: Methods of Factorisation
points: Common factor method: ab + ac = a(b + c)
Grouping method: ax + bx + ay + by = (a + b)(x + y)
Using identities: a² - b² = (a + b)(a - b)
Middle term splitting: x² + (a + b)x + ab = (x + a)(x + b)

formulas.title: Difference of Squares
formulas.formula: a² - b² = (a + b)(a - b)
formulas.explanation: Factorizing difference of two perfect squares

formulas.title: Perfect Square Trinomial
formulas.formula: a² + 2ab + b² = (a + b)²
formulas.explanation: Factorizing perfect square trinomials

realworld.title: Area Calculations
realworld.description: Factoring helps in determining dimensions from area measurements

formulas.title: Cube of a Binomial
formulas.formula: (a + b)³ = a³ + b³ + 3ab(a + b)
formulas.explanation: Expansion of cube of sum of two terms

formulas.title: Sum and Difference of Cubes
formulas.formula: a³ + b³ = (a + b)(a² - ab + b²)
formulas.explanation: Factorizing sum of two cubes

realworld.title: Volume Calculations
realworld.description: Using cubic identities to calculate volumes of containers with given dimensions

notes.title: Introduction to Cartesian Plane
points: Formed by two perpendicular number lines intersecting at origin (0,0)
Quadrants: Four regions formed by axes (I, II, III, IV)

notes.title: Key Concepts
points: Axes divide plane into four quadrants
Positive and negative directions on both axes
Scale: Uniform distance between numbers on axes

formulas.title: Distance from Axes
formulas.formula:
For point (x,y):
- Distance from Y-axis = |x|
- Distance from X-axis = |y|
formulas.explanation: Absolute value of coordinates gives distance from respective axes

realworld.title: City Planning
realworld.description: Using Cartesian coordinates to locate places on city maps and navigation systems

notes.title: Understanding Coordinates
points: Ordered pair (x,y) represents a point's position

formulas.title: Midpoint Formula
formulas.formula:
For points A(x₁,y₁) and B(x₂,y₂):
Midpoint M = ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2)
formulas.explanation: Finds the exact middle point between two given points

formulas.title: Section Formula (Internal Division)
formulas.formula:
Point dividing A(x₁,y₁) and B(x₂,y₂) in ratio m:n is
((mx₂ + nx₁)/(m+n), (my₂ + ny₁)/(m+n))
formulas.explanation: Finds coordinates of a point dividing line segment internally in given ratio

realworld.title: Location Services
realworld.description: Using latitude and longitude (similar to x,y coordinates) to pinpoint locations on Earth

notes.title: Steps to Plot Points
points: Move right if x is positive, left if negative
From that position, move up if y is positive, down if negative
Mark the point at final position

notes.title: Verification of Points
points: Check if point lies on X-axis: y-coordinate must be 0
Check if point lies on Y-axis: x-coordinate must be 0
Check if point lies in a particular quadrant based on signs of (x,y)

formulas.title: Distance Between Two Points
formulas.formula:
For points A(x₁,y₁) and B(x₂,y₂):
Distance AB = √[(x₂ - x₁)² + (y₂ - y₁)²]
formulas.explanation: Pythagorean theorem applied to coordinate geometry

formulas.title: Area of Triangle
formulas.formula:
For vertices A(x₁,y₁), B(x₂,y₂), C(x₃,y₃):
Area = ½ |x₁(y₂ - y₃) + x₂(y₃ - y₁) + x₃(y₁ - y₂)|
formulas.explanation: Shoelace formula for area using coordinates

realworld.title: Architecture Design
realworld.description: Using coordinate geometry to plot room dimensions and furniture placement in architectural designs

realworld.title: Game Development
realworld.description: Positioning game elements and characters using coordinate system

notes.title: Basic Terms and Definitions
points: Point: A location with no size or dimension
Line: A straight one-dimensional figure extending infinitely in both directions
Line Segment: Part of a line with two endpoints
Ray: Part of a line with one endpoint extending infinitely in one direction

notes.title: Pairs of Angles
points: Adjacent Angles: Share a common vertex and side
Linear Pair: Adjacent angles forming a straight line (sum 180°)
Vertically Opposite Angles: Equal angles formed by intersecting lines

formulas.title: Angle Sum Property of a Line
formulas.formula: Sum of angles on a straight line = 180°
formulas.explanation: When two or more angles form a linear pair, their sum is 180 degrees

formulas.title: Vertically Opposite Angles
formulas.formula: ∠AOC = ∠BOD and ∠AOD = ∠BOC
formulas.explanation: When two lines intersect, the vertically opposite angles are equal

realworld.title: Architecture
realworld.description: Using different angles in roof designs and structural support systems

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Understanding angles for bank shots and rebounds in billiards

notes.title: Types of Triangles by Sides
points: Scalene: All sides of different lengths
Isosceles: Two sides equal in length
Equilateral: All three sides equal (each angle 60°)

notes.title: Important Points
points: Exterior angle = Sum of opposite interior angles
Triangle Inequality Theorem: Sum of any two sides > third side

formulas.title: Angle Sum Property
formulas.explanation: The sum of all interior angles of a triangle is always 180 degrees

formulas.title: Exterior Angle Property
formulas.formula:
Exterior angle = Sum of opposite interior angles
∠ACD = ∠A + ∠B
formulas.explanation: An exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two opposite interior angles

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Using triangular structures in roof trusses for strength and stability

realworld.title: Navigation
realworld.description: Using triangles to determine distances and locations in navigation

notes.title: Criteria for Triangle Congruence
points: SAS (Side-Angle-Side): Two sides and included angle equal
ASA (Angle-Side-Angle): Two angles and included side equal
AAS (Angle-Angle-Side): Two angles and non-included side equal
RHS (Right angle-Hypotenuse-Side): Right triangles with hypotenuse and one side equal

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: Ensuring identical components in structures through congruent parts

realworld.title: Manufacturing
realworld.description: Using congruence to ensure identical parts in mass production

notes.title: Inequalities in a Triangle
points: Angle opposite to longer side is larger
Side opposite to larger angle is longer
Sum of any two sides > third side

notes.title: Special Lines in a Triangle
points: Median: Line from vertex to midpoint of opposite side
Altitude: Perpendicular from vertex to opposite side
Angle Bisector: Line that divides angle into two equal parts
Perpendicular Bisector: Perpendicular line passing through midpoint of a side

formulas.title: Pythagoras Theorem
formulas.formula:
In right ΔABC, right-angled at B:
AC² = AB² + BC²
formulas.explanation: In a right-angled triangle, the square of the hypotenuse equals the sum of squares of the other two sides

formulas.title: Heron's Formula
formulas.formula:
Area = √[s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)]
where s = (a+b+c)/2 (semi-perimeter)
formulas.explanation: Formula to find area of a triangle when all three sides are known

realworld.title: Surveying
realworld.description: Using triangle properties to measure large areas of land

realworld.title: Art and Design
realworld.description: Applying triangle properties in creating perspective and proportion in art

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Area is the space occupied by a two-dimensional shape
Measured in square units (cm², m², etc.)
Different shapes have different area formulas

notes.title: Area Formulas
points: Trapezium: ½ × (Sum of parallel sides) × Height

notes.title: Area of Combined Figures
points: Divide complex shapes into simpler ones
Calculate area of each part separately
Add or subtract areas as needed

formulas.title: Area of a Triangle (Heron's Formula)
formulas.formula:
Area = √[s(s-a)(s-b)(s-c)]
where s = (a+b+c)/2 (semi-perimeter)
formulas.explanation: Used when all three sides of triangle are known

formulas.title: Area of a Rhombus
formulas.formula:
Area = ½ × d₁ × d₂
where d₁ and d₂ are lengths of diagonals
formulas.explanation: Product of diagonals divided by 2

realworld.title: Flooring and Carpeting
realworld.description: Calculating area to determine amount of flooring material needed

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Measuring field areas for crop planning and irrigation

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Total area of all faces/surfaces of a 3D shape
Measured in square units (cm², m², etc.)

notes.title: Types of Surface Areas
points: Lateral Surface Area (LSA): Area of vertical faces only
Total Surface Area (TSA): LSA + Area of bases
Curved Surface Area (CSA): For curved surfaces like cylinders and cones

formulas.title: Cuboid
formulas.formula:
LSA = 2h(l + b)
TSA = 2(lb + bh + hl)
formulas.explanation: l = length, b = breadth, h = height

formulas.title: Cylinder
formulas.formula:
CSA = 2πrh
TSA = 2πr(r + h)
formulas.explanation: r = radius, h = height

formulas.title: Cone
formulas.formula:
CSA = πrl
TSA = πr(r + l)
where l = √(r² + h²) is slant height
formulas.explanation: r = radius, h = height, l = slant height

realworld.title: Packaging
realworld.description: Calculating material needed for product packaging

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Determining amount of paint or wallpaper needed for walls

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Measured in cubic units (cm³, m³, etc.)

notes.title: Capacity
points: Volume of fluid a container can hold
Common units: liters, milliliters, cubic meters

formulas.title: Volume of a Prism
formulas.formula: Volume = Base Area × Height
formulas.explanation: Applies to all prisms including rectangular and triangular prisms

formulas.title: Volume of a Pyramid
formulas.formula: Volume = ⅓ × Base Area × Height
formulas.explanation: Applies to all pyramids including square and triangular pyramids

formulas.title: Volume of a Hemisphere
formulas.formula:
Volume = ⅔πr³
Curved Surface Area = 2πr²
Total Surface Area = 3πr²
formulas.explanation: Half of a sphere with radius r

realworld.title: Liquid Storage
realworld.description: Calculating storage capacity of water tanks and containers

realworld.title: Manufacturing
realworld.description: Determining amount of material needed to manufacture solid objects

realworld.title: Transportation
realworld.description: Calculating how much cargo can fit in shipping containers

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Statistics is the science of collecting, organizing, analyzing, and interpreting data
Data: Collection of facts and figures for analysis
Primary Data: Collected directly from the source for specific purpose
Secondary Data: Collected by someone else for their purpose

notes.title: Types of Data
points: Raw Data: Unorganized collection of observations
Array: Arrangement of data in ascending/descending order
Grouped Data: Data organized into classes or intervals

realworld.title: Market Research
realworld.description: Companies collect data to understand customer needs and preferences

realworld.title: Census
realworld.description: Government collects demographic data for policy making and resource allocation

notes.title: Frequency Distribution
points: Frequency: Number of times an observation occurs
Class Interval: Grouping of data into ranges
Class Limits: Lower and upper values of a class
Class Mark: Mid-value of a class interval

notes.title: Construction of Frequency Table
points: Prepare frequency table with tally marks

formulas.title: Class Mark
formulas.formula: Class Mark = (Lower Limit + Upper Limit) / 2
formulas.explanation: Mid-point of a class interval

formulas.title: Class Size
formulas.formula: Class Size = Upper Limit - Lower Limit
formulas.explanation: Width of each class interval

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: Schools tabulate exam scores to analyze performance patterns

realworld.title: Healthcare
realworld.description: Hospitals organize patient data by age groups, conditions, etc.

notes.title: Types of Graphs
points: Bar Graph: Compares categories using rectangular bars
Histogram: Represents frequency distribution of continuous data
Frequency Polygon: Line graph showing frequency distribution
Pie Chart: Circular graph showing proportions

notes.title: Choosing the Right Graph
points: Bar Graph: For categorical data comparison
Line Graph: For trends over time
Pie Chart: For showing parts of a whole

formulas.title: Angle for Pie Chart
formulas.formula: Angle = (Frequency/Total Frequency) × 360°
formulas.explanation: Calculates the angle for each sector in a pie chart

realworld.title: Business Analytics
realworld.description: Companies use graphs to visualize sales trends and performance

realworld.title: Weather Forecasting
realworld.description: Meteorologists use graphs to show temperature and rainfall patterns

notes.title: Measures of Central Tendency
points: Mean: Average of all observations (Sum of all values/Number of values)
Median: Middle value when data is arranged in order
Mode: Most frequently occurring value in the data

notes.title: When to Use Which Measure
points: Mean: For data with no extreme values
Mode: For categorical data or most common value

formulas.title: Mean (Ungrouped Data)
formulas.formula: Mean = (Sum of all observations) / (Number of observations)
formulas.explanation: Arithmetic average of all data points

formulas.title: Median (Ungrouped Data)
formulas.formula:
For odd n: Value at (n+1)/2 position
For even n: Average of values at n/2 and (n/2)+1 positions
formulas.explanation: Middle value of ordered data set

formulas.title: Mode (Ungrouped Data)
formulas.formula: Value that appears most frequently in the data set
formulas.explanation: Most common observation

formulas.title: Mean (Grouped Data)
formulas.formula:
Mean = (Σfᵢxᵢ) / (Σfᵢ)
where fᵢ = frequency, xᵢ = class mark
formulas.explanation: Weighted average using class marks and frequencies

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: Schools calculate mean, median, and mode of exam scores to evaluate overall performance

realworld.title: Economics
realworld.description: Economists use median income to understand the typical earnings in a population

realworld.title: Retail
realworld.description: Stores track the mode of product sales to manage stock levels effectively

notes.title: Basic Definitions
points: Probability measures the likelihood of an event occurring
Trial: A single performance of a random experiment
Outcome: Possible result of a trial
Event: One or more outcomes of an experiment

notes.title: Key Concepts
points: Sample Space (S): Set of all possible outcomes
Favorable Outcomes: Outcomes that satisfy the event
Equally Likely Outcomes: All outcomes have same chance
Probability = (Number of favorable outcomes) / (Total number of possible outcomes)

formulas.title: Probability Formula
formulas.formula:
P(E) = n(E)/n(S)
where:
P(E) = Probability of event E
n(E) = Number of favorable outcomes
n(S) = Total number of possible outcomes
formulas.explanation: Basic probability formula for equally likely outcomes

realworld.title: Weather Forecasting
realworld.description: Meteorologists use probability to predict weather conditions

realworld.title: Games
realworld.description: Probability helps in understanding chances in games of chance

notes.title: Understanding Experimental Probability
points: Based on actual experiments and observations
Formula: P(E) = (Number of trials where event occurred) / (Total number of trials)
May vary with number of trials
Tends to theoretical probability with large number of trials

notes.title: Important Points
points: Experimental probability approaches theoretical probability as number of trials increases (Law of Large Numbers)
Useful when theoretical probability is difficult to calculate

formulas.title: Experimental Probability Formula
formulas.formula: P'(E) = (Number of times event E occurs) / (Total number of trials)
formulas.explanation: Experimental probability is based on actual experimental data

realworld.title: Quality Control
realworld.description: Manufacturers use experimental probability to determine defect rates

realworld.title: Medical Research
realworld.description: Clinical trials use experimental probability to test new treatments

notes.title: Problem Solving Approach
points: Identify total number of possible outcomes

formulas.title: Probability of Complementary Event
formulas.formula:
P(E') = 1 - P(E)
where E' is the complement of event E
formulas.explanation: Probability of an event not occurring

formulas.title: Probability of Sure and Impossible Events
formulas.formula:
P(sure event) = 1
P(impossible event) = 0
formulas.explanation: Probabilities of certain and impossible events

realworld.title: Risk Assessment
realworld.description: Insurance companies use probability to calculate premiums and risks

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Coaches use probability to develop game strategies and make decisions

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Physical Quantity: Any measurable property of a material or system
Fundamental Quantities: Cannot be defined in terms of other quantities (e.g., length, mass, time)
Derived Quantities: Expressed in terms of fundamental quantities (e.g., speed, force, energy)
Scalar Quantities: Have only magnitude (e.g., mass, distance, speed)
Vector Quantities: Have both magnitude and direction (e.g., velocity, force, acceleration)

notes.title: Systems of Measurement
points: SI System: International System of Units (modern form of metric system)

formulas.title: Density
formulas.formula:
Density (ρ) = Mass (m) / Volume (V)
Units: kg/m³ (SI), g/cm³ (CGS)
formulas.explanation: Mass per unit volume of a substance

formulas.title: Speed
formulas.formula:
Speed = Distance / Time
Units: m/s (SI), cm/s (CGS)
formulas.explanation: Distance traveled per unit time

realworld.title: Construction
realworld.description: Using density to calculate required quantities of construction materials

formulas.title: Unit Conversion
formulas.explanation: Common unit conversions in measurements

realworld.title: International Trade
realworld.description: Using SI units for consistency in global trade and communication

notes.title: Length Measurement
points: Meter Scale: For measuring lengths from 1 mm to 1 m
Vernier Calipers: Measures up to 0.1 mm accuracy
Screw Gauge: Measures up to 0.01 mm accuracy

notes.title: Mass Measurement
points: Beam Balance: Compares unknown mass with known masses
Electronic Balance: Digital display, high precision
Spring Balance: Measures weight (force due to gravity)

notes.title: Time Measurement
points: Digital Clock: For precise time measurement
Pendulum Clock: Based on periodic motion

formulas.title: Vernier Caliper Reading
formulas.formula: Total Reading = Main Scale Reading + (Vernier Scale Reading × Least Count)
formulas.explanation: For precise length measurement using Vernier Calipers

formulas.title: Screw Gauge Reading
formulas.formula: Total Reading = Pitch Scale Reading + (Circular Scale Reading × Least Count)
formulas.explanation: For very precise measurements using Screw Gauge

realworld.title: Laboratory Work
realworld.description: Using appropriate instruments for different levels of measurement precision

notes.title: Types of Errors
points: Systematic Errors: Consistent, can be corrected (e.g., zero error in instruments)
Random Errors: Unpredictable variations (e.g., parallax error)
Gross Errors: Mistakes in measurement (e.g., wrong reading)

notes.title: Minimizing Errors
points: Taking multiple readings and calculating average
Avoiding parallax error by proper eye position
Using instruments with appropriate least count
Checking for zero error and applying corrections

formulas.title: Absolute Error
formulas.formula: Absolute Error = |Measured Value - True Value|
formulas.explanation: Magnitude of difference between measured and true value

formulas.title: Relative Error
formulas.formula: Relative Error = (Absolute Error / True Value) × 100%
formulas.explanation: Expressed as percentage of true value

formulas.title: Mean Absolute Error
formulas.formula: Mean Absolute Error = (Σ|Δxᵢ|) / n
formulas.explanation: Average of absolute errors in multiple measurements

realworld.title: Quality Control
realworld.description: Manufacturers set acceptable error margins for products

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Distance: Total path length covered by an object (scalar quantity)
Displacement: Shortest distance between initial and final positions (vector quantity)

notes.title: Key Differences
points: Distance depends on path, Displacement depends only on initial and final positions
Distance is always positive, Displacement can be positive/negative/zero
Distance is a scalar, Displacement is a vector

formulas.title: Displacement in 1D
formulas.formula:
Δx = x_f - x_i
where:
Δx = Displacement
x_f = Final position
x_i = Initial position
formulas.explanation: Displacement is the change in position

realworld.title: Navigation
realworld.description: GPS calculates displacement for navigation, not just distance

notes.title: Definitions
points: Speed: Distance traveled per unit time (scalar)
Average speed = Total distance / Total time
Average velocity = Total displacement / Total time

notes.title: Types of Speed
points: Instantaneous Speed: Speed at a particular instant

formulas.title: Average Speed
formulas.formula:
Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time
Units: m/s, km/h
formulas.explanation: Total distance covered divided by total time taken

formulas.title: Average Velocity
formulas.formula:
Average Velocity = Total Displacement / Total Time
Units: m/s (with direction)
formulas.explanation: Net displacement divided by total time

realworld.title: Transportation
realworld.description: Speed limits are set based on average speed for safety

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Rate of change of velocity with time
Vector quantity (has both magnitude and direction)
Can be positive (speeding up) or negative (slowing down)

notes.title: Types of Acceleration
points: Uniform Acceleration: Constant rate of change of velocity
Non-uniform Acceleration: Changing rate of change of velocity

formulas.title: Average Acceleration
formulas.formula:
a = (v - u) / t
where:
a = acceleration
v = final velocity
u = initial velocity
t = time
formulas.explanation: Change in velocity per unit time

realworld.title: Vehicle Safety
realworld.description: Understanding acceleration helps design safer braking systems

notes.title: First Equation of Motion
points: Relates final velocity to initial velocity, acceleration, and time

notes.title: Second Equation of Motion
points: Relates displacement to initial velocity, acceleration, and time

notes.title: Third Equation of Motion
points: Relates final velocity to initial velocity, acceleration, and displacement

formulas.title: First Equation
formulas.formula:
v = u + at
where:
v = final velocity
u = initial velocity
a = acceleration
t = time
formulas.explanation: Final velocity after time t

formulas.title: Second Equation
formulas.formula:
s = ut + ½at²
where:
s = displacement
u = initial velocity
a = acceleration
t = time
formulas.explanation: Displacement in time t

formulas.title: Third Equation
formulas.formula:
v² = u² + 2as
where:
v = final velocity
u = initial velocity
a = acceleration
s = displacement
formulas.explanation: Relates velocities to displacement

realworld.title: Projectile Motion
realworld.description: Used in sports like basketball and cricket to predict ball trajectory

realworld.title: Transportation
realworld.description: Helps in designing safer vehicles and traffic systems

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Force is a push or pull that can change the state of motion of an object
It is a vector quantity (has both magnitude and direction)

notes.title: Types of Forces
points: Contact Forces: Applied, Normal, Tension, Friction
Balanced Forces: Net force is zero (no acceleration)
Unbalanced Forces: Net force is not zero (causes acceleration)

formulas.title: Force Formula
formulas.formula:
F = m × a
where:
F = Force (N)
m = mass (kg)
a = acceleration (m/s²)
formulas.explanation: Newton's Second Law of Motion

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Batsman applies force to hit the ball

realworld.title: Transportation
realworld.description: Engine applies force to move the car forward

notes.title: First Law (Law of Inertia)
points: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force
Also called the Law of Inertia
Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion

notes.title: Second Law (Force and Acceleration)
points: The acceleration of an object depends on the net force acting on it and its mass
Acceleration is in the same direction as the net force

notes.title: Third Law (Action-Reaction)
points: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction
Action and reaction forces act on different objects

formulas.title: Newton's Second Law
formulas.formula:
ΣF = m × a
where:
ΣF = Net force (N)
m = mass (kg)
a = acceleration (m/s²)
formulas.explanation: Net force equals mass times acceleration

realworld.title: Rocket Launch
realworld.description: Rocket pushes exhaust gases down (action), gases push rocket up (reaction)

realworld.title: Seatbelts
realworld.description: Prevent passengers from continuing to move forward when a car stops suddenly

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Momentum is the product of an object's mass and velocity
Vector quantity (has both magnitude and direction)

notes.title: Impulse
points: Change in momentum of an object
Impulse = Force × Time = Change in momentum

formulas.title: Momentum
formulas.formula:
p = m × v
where:
p = momentum (kg·m/s)
m = mass (kg)
v = velocity (m/s)
formulas.explanation: Momentum is mass times velocity

formulas.title: Impulse-Momentum Theorem
formulas.formula:
F × t = mΔv = Δp
where:
F = Force (N)
t = time (s)
m = mass (kg)
Δv = change in velocity (m/s)
Δp = change in momentum (kg·m/s)
formulas.explanation: Impulse equals change in momentum

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Moving hands back while catching increases time of impact, reducing force

realworld.title: Vehicle Safety
realworld.description: Increase impact time to reduce force on passengers

notes.title: Law of Conservation of Momentum
points: In an isolated system, the total momentum remains constant
Total momentum before collision = Total momentum after collision
Applies to both elastic and inelastic collisions

notes.title: Types of Collisions
points: Elastic Collision: Both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved
Inelastic Collision: Only momentum is conserved, some kinetic energy is converted to other forms
Perfectly Inelastic Collision: Objects stick together after collision

formulas.title: Conservation of Momentum
formulas.formula:
m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = m₁v₁ + m₂v₂
where:
m = mass
u = initial velocity
v = final velocity
formulas.explanation: Total momentum before equals total momentum after collision

formulas.title: Perfectly Inelastic Collision
formulas.formula:
m₁u₁ + m₂u₂ = (m₁ + m₂)v
where:
v = common velocity after collision
formulas.explanation: Objects stick together after collision

realworld.title: Space Exploration
realworld.description: Spacecraft use conservation of momentum for docking maneuvers

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Collisions between billiard balls demonstrate conservation of momentum

notes.title: Basic Classification
points: Matter is anything that has mass and occupies space
Pure Substances: Elements and compounds with fixed composition
Mixtures: Combination of two or more substances in any proportion

notes.title: Types of Mixtures
points: Homogeneous Mixtures: Uniform composition throughout (e.g., salt water, air)
Heterogeneous Mixtures: Non-uniform composition (e.g., soil, salad)
Solutions: Homogeneous mixtures of solute and solvent

formulas.title: Mass Percentage
formulas.formula: Mass % = (Mass of component / Total mass of mixture) × 100
formulas.explanation: Expresses concentration of a component in a mixture

realworld.title: Cooking
realworld.description: Making salt water or sugar solutions in cooking

notes.title: Solid State
points: Particles are closely packed in fixed positions

notes.title: Liquid State
points: Definite volume but no fixed shape
Particles are close but can move past each other

notes.title: Gaseous State
points: Particles are far apart and move freely

formulas.title: Density
formulas.formula:
Density = Mass / Volume
Units: g/cm³ or kg/m³
formulas.explanation: Mass per unit volume of a substance

realworld.title: Weather
realworld.description: Water changes states between solid, liquid, and gas in nature

notes.title: Physical Changes
points: Examples: Melting of ice, boiling of water, dissolving salt
Involves changes in physical properties only

notes.title: Chemical Changes
points: New substances with different properties are formed
Examples: Burning of paper, rusting of iron, cooking food

formulas.title: Chemical Equation
formulas.formula:
Reactants → Products
Example: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O
formulas.explanation: Represents a chemical change

realworld.title: Cooking
realworld.description: Cooking food involves chemical changes that make it more digestible and flavorful

realworld.title: Photography
realworld.description: Traditional photography uses light-sensitive chemicals that undergo chemical changes

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Atom: Smallest unit of matter that retains the properties of an element
Molecule: Group of two or more atoms chemically bonded together
Element: Pure substance made of only one type of atom
Compound: Substance formed by chemical combination of two or more elements

notes.title: Atomic Theory
points: Dalton's Atomic Theory (1808): First scientific theory of atoms
Modern Atomic Theory: Incorporates subatomic particles and quantum mechanics
Atoms are divisible and can be transformed in nuclear reactions

formulas.title: Molecular Mass
formulas.formula:
Molecular Mass = Sum of atomic masses of all atoms in the molecule
Example: H₂O = (2×1) + 16 = 18 u
formulas.explanation: Expressed in atomic mass units (u)

realworld.title: Water Purification
realworld.description: Understanding water's molecular structure helps in designing effective purification methods

notes.title: Electrons
points: Orbit the nucleus in specific energy levels

formulas.title: Atomic Number (Z)
formulas.formula: Z = Number of protons = Number of electrons (in neutral atom)
formulas.explanation: Identifies the element

formulas.title: Mass Number (A)
formulas.formula: A = Number of protons + Number of neutrons
formulas.explanation: Total number of nucleons in the nucleus

realworld.title: Medical Imaging
realworld.description: PET scans use positrons (antimatter electrons) for medical imaging

notes.title: Thomson's Model (Plum Pudding Model)
points: Atoms as positively charged spheres with embedded electrons
Couldn't explain Rutherford's gold foil experiment results

notes.title: Rutherford's Nuclear Model
points: Dense, positively charged nucleus at center
Electrons orbit the nucleus like planets around the sun
Most of the atom is empty space

notes.title: Bohr's Model
points: Electrons move in fixed circular orbits (energy levels)
Electrons can jump between energy levels by absorbing/emitting energy
Explained hydrogen spectrum but had limitations for larger atoms

notes.title: Quantum Mechanical Model
points: Uses quantum numbers to describe electron locations
Most accurate model of atomic structure

formulas.title: Bohr's Energy Levels
formulas.formula:
Eₙ = -13.6/n² eV
where n = principal quantum number (1,2,3...)
formulas.explanation: Energy of electron in nth orbit of hydrogen atom

formulas.title: De Broglie Wavelength
formulas.formula:
λ = h/mv
where:
λ = wavelength
h = Planck's constant (6.626 × 10⁻³⁴ Js)
m = mass
v = velocity
formulas.explanation: Matter waves concept in quantum mechanics

realworld.title: Lasers
realworld.description: Based on electron transitions between energy levels

realworld.title: Electronics
realworld.description: Understanding atomic structure led to development of transistors and computer chips

notes.title: Epithelial Tissue
points: Covers body surfaces and lines cavities
Types: Squamous, Cuboidal, Columnar, Ciliated, Glandular
Found in skin, digestive tract, glands

notes.title: Connective Tissue
points: Most abundant and widely distributed tissue
Types: Areolar, Adipose, Bone, Cartilage, Blood, Lymph
Contains cells, fibers, and ground substance

notes.title: Muscular Tissue
points: Contains contractile proteins: Actin and Myosin

notes.title: Nervous Tissue
points: Makes up brain, spinal cord, and nerves

formulas.title: Neuron Conduction Speed
formulas.formula: Speed = Distance / Time (m/s)
formulas.explanation: Speed of nerve impulse conduction varies with axon diameter and myelination

realworld.title: Medical Field
realworld.description: Growing artificial tissues for medical transplants and research

notes.title: Human Digestive System
points: Alimentary Canal: Mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine
Accessory Organs: Salivary glands, liver, pancreas
Processes: Ingestion, digestion, absorption, assimilation, egestion

notes.title: Types of Nutrition
points: Holozoic: Ingestion of complex organic matter (e.g., humans)
Saprophytic: Feeding on dead and decaying matter
Parasitic: Deriving nutrition from host organisms

notes.title: Digestive Enzymes
points: Lipase: Breaks down fats (pancreas, small intestine)

formulas.title: Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR)
formulas.formula: BMR (kcal/day) = 88.362 + (13.397 × weight in kg) + (4.799 × height in cm) - (5.677 × age in years)
formulas.explanation: Estimates daily energy expenditure at rest (for males; different formula for females)

realworld.title: Health & Nutrition
realworld.description: Understanding nutrition helps in planning balanced meals for different age groups

notes.title: Respiratory Organs
points: Frogs: Skin, mouth, lungs (cutaneous, buccopharyngeal, pulmonary)

notes.title: Human Respiratory System
points: Pathway: Nostrils → Nasal cavity → Pharynx → Larynx → Trachea → Bronchi → Bronchioles → Alveoli

notes.title: Mechanism of Breathing
points: Inspiration: Diaphragm contracts, rib cage moves up and out (inhalation)
Expiration: Diaphragm relaxes, rib cage moves down and in (exhalation)

formulas.title: Tidal Volume
formulas.formula: Average Tidal Volume = 500 mL (in adults)
formulas.explanation: Volume of air inhaled/exhaled during normal breathing

formulas.title: Vital Capacity
formulas.formula:
VC = TV + IRV + ERV
(TV = Tidal Volume, IRV = Inspiratory Reserve Volume, ERV = Expiratory Reserve Volume)
formulas.explanation: Maximum air that can be exhaled after maximum inhalation

realworld.title: Medical Field
realworld.description: Used to diagnose and monitor respiratory conditions like asthma and COPD

notes.title: Types of Animal Tissues
points: Epithelial Tissue: Covers body surfaces and lines cavities
Connective Tissue: Supports and connects body parts (e.g., bone, cartilage, blood)
Muscular Tissue: Responsible for movement (skeletal, smooth, cardiac)

formulas.title: Tissue Growth Rate
formulas.formula: Growth Rate = (Final Mass - Initial Mass) / Time Period
formulas.explanation: Measures how quickly animal tissues grow over time

realworld.title: Medical Science
realworld.description: Scientists grow animal tissues in labs for medical research and transplantation

notes.title: Types of Nutrition
points: Holozoic: Ingestion of complex organic matter (humans, dogs)
Saprophytic: Feeding on dead and decaying matter (fungi, some bacteria)
Parasitic: Deriving nutrition from other living organisms (tapeworms, leeches)

notes.title: Human Digestive System
points: Alimentary canal: Mouth → Oesophagus → Stomach → Small intestine → Large intestine
Associated glands: Salivary glands, Liver, Pancreas
Processes: Ingestion, Digestion, Absorption, Assimilation, Egestion

formulas.title: Energy from Food
formulas.formula: Energy (kcal) = (Protein × 4) + (Carbs × 4) + (Fats × 9)
formulas.explanation: Calculates energy obtained from macronutrients in food

realworld.title: Animal Husbandry
realworld.description: Proper nutrition is crucial for livestock health and productivity

notes.title: Types of Respiration
points: Anaerobic: Without oxygen (some parasites, muscle cells during heavy exercise)

notes.title: Human Respiratory System
points: Nostrils → Nasal cavity → Pharynx → Larynx → Trachea → Bronchi → Bronchioles → Alveoli

formulas.title: Respiratory Quotient (RQ)
formulas.formula: RQ = CO₂ produced / O₂ consumed
formulas.explanation: Ratio of CO₂ produced to O₂ consumed during respiration

realworld.title: Medical Science
realworld.description: Measure lung capacity and function to diagnose respiratory disorders

notes.title: Daily Hygiene Practices
points: Hand washing: Before meals, after using toilet, and when dirty
Oral hygiene: Brushing twice daily, flossing, and tongue cleaning
Bathing: Daily with soap, especially in tropical climates
Nail care: Regular trimming and cleaning

notes.title: Hygiene During Adolescence
points: Increased sweat and body odor management

formulas.title: Hand Washing Effectiveness
formulas.formula: Effectiveness = (Time Spent × Technique × Soap Use) / Contamination Level
formulas.explanation: Proper hand washing requires at least 20 seconds with soap and proper technique

realworld.title: Public Health
realworld.description: Regular hand washing can reduce diarrheal diseases by 30-48%

notes.title: Essential Nutrients
points: Carbohydrates: Main energy source (rice, wheat, potatoes)
Proteins: Growth and repair (pulses, eggs, meat)

formulas.title: Body Mass Index (BMI)
formulas.formula: BMI = Weight (kg) / (Height (m))²
formulas.explanation: Measures body fat based on height and weight

realworld.title: Nutrition
realworld.description: Visual guide showing ideal portions of different food groups for a balanced meal

formulas.title: Basic Reproduction Number (R₀)
formulas.formula: R₀ = Transmission rate × Contact rate × Duration of infectiousness
formulas.explanation: Estimates how many people one infected person can spread the disease to

realworld.title: Public Health
realworld.description: Preventive measures like immunization help control communicable diseases

formulas.title: Heart Rate Zones
formulas.formula:
Maximum Heart Rate = 220 - Age
Target Heart Rate = 50-85% of Maximum Heart Rate
formulas.explanation: Helps in maintaining optimal exercise intensity

realworld.title: Healthcare
realworld.description: Focus on preventing and managing NCDs through lifestyle changes

notes.title: Government Initiatives
points: Tamil Nadu Health Systems Reform Program

formulas.title: Herd Immunity Threshold
formulas.formula:
HIT = 1 - (1/R₀)
where R₀ is basic reproduction number
formulas.explanation: Percentage of population that needs to be immune to stop disease spread

realworld.title: Public Health
realworld.description: Monitoring disease patterns to implement timely control measures

realworld.title: Community Health
realworld.description: Accredited Social Health Activists play crucial role in rural healthcare delivery

notes.title: Definition and Types
points: Ecosystem: A community of living organisms interacting with their physical environment
Natural Ecosystems: Forests, grasslands, deserts, aquatic
Artificial Ecosystems: Crop fields, gardens, aquariums

notes.title: Structural Components
points: Abiotic Components: Air, water, soil, sunlight, temperature

formulas.title: Net Primary Productivity (NPP)
formulas.formula:
NPP = GPP - R
where:
GPP = Gross Primary Production
R = Respiratory loss
formulas.explanation: Amount of biomass available for consumers in an ecosystem

realworld.title: Conservation
realworld.description: Identifying and protecting ecologically rich areas

notes.title: Abiotic Factors
points: Edaphic: Soil type, pH, mineral content

formulas.title: pH Scale
formulas.formula:
pH = -log₁₀[H⁺]
where [H⁺] is hydrogen ion concentration
formulas.explanation: Measures acidity (0-7) or alkalinity (7-14) of soil/water

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Measuring abiotic factors for optimal crop production

notes.title: Food Chain
points: Trophic levels: Producers → Primary consumers → Secondary consumers → Tertiary consumers
Energy loss at each level (10% rule)

formulas.title: Energy Transfer Efficiency
formulas.formula: Energy at Trophic Level n+1 = Energy at Trophic Level n × 0.1
formulas.explanation: Only 10% of energy is transferred between trophic levels

realworld.title: Wildlife Management
realworld.description: Understanding food webs to protect ecologically important species

formulas.title: Water Footprint
formulas.formula: WF = Direct Water Use + Virtual Water Use
formulas.explanation: Total volume of freshwater used to produce goods and services

realworld.title: Urban Planning
realworld.description: Incorporating sustainable resource use in construction

notes.title: Types of Pollution
points: Air Pollution: Smog, greenhouse gases, particulates
Water Pollution: Industrial waste, sewage, oil spills
Soil Pollution: Pesticides, heavy metals, waste disposal

formulas.title: Air Quality Index (AQI)
formulas.formula: AQI = (I_high - I_low)/(C_high - C_low) × (C - C_low) + I_low
formulas.explanation: Numerical scale for reporting air quality (0-500)

realworld.title: Public Health
realworld.description: Using AQI to issue health advisories

notes.title: Conservation Methods
points: In-situ Conservation: National parks, wildlife sanctuaries, biosphere reserves
Ex-situ Conservation: Zoos, botanical gardens, seed banks

notes.title: Sustainable Development
points: Meeting present needs without compromising future generations

formulas.title: Ecological Footprint
formulas.formula: EF = (Σ (Amount of resource consumed / World average yield)) × Equivalence Factor × Yield Factor
formulas.explanation: Measures human demand on Earth's ecosystems

realworld.title: Corporate Responsibility
realworld.description: Market-based approach to controlling greenhouse gas emissions

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: School programs promoting environmental awareness

notes.title: Properties of Light
points: Light is a form of electromagnetic radiation

notes.title: Electromagnetic Spectrum
points: Other types: Radio waves, microwaves, infrared, ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma rays
Order of increasing frequency: Radio < Microwaves < IR < Visible < UV < X-rays < Gamma

formulas.title: Wave Equation
formulas.formula:
v = fλ
where:
v = velocity of light (m/s)
f = frequency (Hz)
λ = wavelength (m)
formulas.explanation: Relates speed, frequency, and wavelength of light

realworld.title: Optical Communication
realworld.description: Uses total internal reflection to transmit data as light pulses

notes.title: Laws of Reflection
points: First Law: Incident ray, reflected ray, and normal all lie in the same plane
Second Law: Angle of incidence (i) = Angle of reflection (r)

notes.title: Types of Reflection
points: Diffuse Reflection: From rough surfaces (paper, walls)
Multiple Reflections: In multiple mirror systems

formulas.title: Law of Reflection
formulas.formula:
∠i = ∠r
where:
∠i = angle of incidence
∠r = angle of reflection
formulas.explanation: The angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection

realworld.title: Safety
realworld.description: Convex mirrors provide wider field of view in vehicles

notes.title: Basic Concepts
points: Bending of light when passing between different media
Due to change in speed of light
Causes: Twinkling of stars, apparent depth, mirages

notes.title: Laws of Refraction
points: First Law: Incident ray, refracted ray, and normal lie in same plane
Critical angle and total internal reflection

formulas.title: Refractive Index
formulas.formula:
n = c/v = sin i / sin r
where:
n = refractive index
c = speed of light in vacuum
v = speed of light in medium
i = angle of incidence
r = angle of refraction
formulas.explanation: Measure of how much light bends when entering a medium

formulas.title: Critical Angle
formulas.formula:
sin C = 1/n
where:
C = critical angle
n = refractive index of denser medium
formulas.explanation: Angle of incidence beyond which total internal reflection occurs

realworld.title: Optical Instruments
realworld.description: Used in cameras, microscopes, and eyeglasses to bend light

notes.title: Plane Mirrors
points: Virtual, erect, and same size as object

notes.title: Spherical Mirrors
points: Concave Mirror: Converging mirror, can form real and virtual images
Convex Mirror: Diverging mirror, always forms virtual, erect, and diminished images
Uses: Headlights, shaving mirrors, security mirrors

formulas.title: Mirror Formula
formulas.formula:
1/f = 1/v + 1/u
where:
f = focal length
v = image distance
u = object distance
formulas.explanation: Relates object distance, image distance, and focal length

formulas.title: Magnification
formulas.formula:
m = -v/u = h'/h
where:
m = magnification
v = image distance
u = object distance
h' = image height
h = object height
formulas.explanation: Ratio of image height to object height

realworld.title: Medical Field
realworld.description: Concave mirrors provide magnified images of teeth

notes.title: Optical Instruments
points: Cameras: Lens systems for image formation

notes.title: Everyday Applications
points: Periscopes: Uses plane mirrors for seeing around corners
Spectacles: Corrective lenses for vision defects

formulas.title: Lens Power
formulas.formula:
P = 1/f
where:
P = power in diopters (D)
f = focal length in meters
formulas.explanation: Measure of the degree of convergence or divergence of light

realworld.title: Astronomy
realworld.description: Use mirrors and lenses to observe distant celestial objects

realworld.title: Entertainment
realworld.description: Use lenses to project enlarged images on screens

notes.title: Newton's Law of Gravitation
points: Every object in the universe attracts every other object with a force
Force is directly proportional to the product of their masses
Force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them

notes.title: Characteristics
points: Independent of the medium between objects
Follows Newton's Third Law of Motion

formulas.title: Gravitational Force
formulas.formula:
F = G (m₁m₂)/r²
where:
F = Gravitational force
G = Universal gravitational constant (6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ Nm²/kg²)
m₁, m₂ = Masses of two objects
r = Distance between centers of masses
formulas.explanation: Calculates the force of attraction between any two objects with mass

realworld.title: Astronomy
realworld.description: Explains the motion of planets around the Sun and satellites around planets

notes.title: Mass
points: Amount of matter in a body

notes.title: Weight
points: Force with which a body is attracted towards Earth
W = mg (m = mass, g = acceleration due to gravity)

formulas.title: Weight Calculation
formulas.formula:
W = m × g
where:
W = Weight (N)
m = Mass (kg)
g = Acceleration due to gravity (9.8 m/s² on Earth's surface)
formulas.explanation: Calculates the weight of an object based on its mass and local gravitational acceleration

realworld.title: Space Exploration
realworld.description: Astronauts experience weightlessness in space due to free-fall conditions, though their mass remains the same

notes.title: Concepts
points: Motion under the influence of gravity alone
Acceleration due to gravity (g) = 9.8 m/s² (on Earth's surface)
All objects, regardless of mass, fall with same acceleration (in vacuum)
Equations of motion apply with a = g

notes.title: Terminal Velocity
points: Maximum velocity attained by a falling object
Occurs when air resistance equals weight
Depends on shape and size of object

formulas.title: Free Fall Equations
formulas.formula:
v = u + gt
h = ut + ½gt²
v² = u² + 2gh
where:
v = final velocity
u = initial velocity
g = acceleration due to gravity
t = time
h = height
formulas.explanation: Equations to calculate various parameters of an object in free fall

realworld.title: Sports
realworld.description: Skydivers reach terminal velocity during free fall before deploying parachutes

notes.title: Thrust
points: Force acting normally on a surface
Example: Weight of an object is thrust on the surface it rests

notes.title: Pressure
points: Increases with decreasing area for same force
Liquids and gases exert pressure in all directions

formulas.title: Pressure Calculation
formulas.formula:
P = F/A
where:
P = Pressure (Pa)
F = Force (N)
A = Area (m²)
formulas.explanation: Pressure is inversely proportional to the area on which force is applied

realworld.title: Engineering
realworld.description: Wider foundations reduce pressure on soil to prevent sinking

notes.title: Archimedes' Principle
points: When a body is immersed in a fluid, it experiences an upward force called buoyant force
Buoyant force equals the weight of the fluid displaced
Explains why objects float or sink
Apparent loss in weight = weight of fluid displaced

formulas.title: Buoyant Force
formulas.formula:
F_b = ρVg
where:
F_b = Buoyant force (N)
ρ = Density of fluid (kg/m³)
V = Volume of displaced fluid (m³)
g = Acceleration due to gravity (m/s²)
formulas.explanation: Calculates the upward force exerted by a fluid on an immersed object

realworld.title: Marine Engineering
realworld.description: Ships are designed to displace a volume of water whose weight is equal to the ship's weight, allowing them to float

realworld.title: Medical
realworld.description: Lactometers use buoyancy principle to measure milk purity

notes.title: Human Evolution Timeline
points: Australopithecus (4-2 million years ago): Bipedal, small brain
Homo habilis (2.4-1.4 mya): First tool users
Homo erectus (1.9 mya-143,000 ya): First to use fire, migrated out of Africa
Homo neanderthalensis (400,000-40,000 ya): Lived in Europe and Asia

notes.title: Key Discoveries
points: Bhimbetka rock shelters - India, showing early human life

formulas.title: Dating Methods
formulas.formula: Carbon-14 Dating: t = [ln(Nf/No)/(-0.693)] × t1/2
formulas.explanation: Used to determine the age of organic materials up to 50,000 years old

realworld.title: Anthropology
realworld.description: Tracing human migration patterns through DNA analysis and fossil records

notes.title: Mesolithic Age (10,000 - 8,000 BCE)
points: Middle Stone Age: Development of microliths

notes.title: Neolithic Age (8,000 - 3,000 BCE)
points: New Stone Age: Agriculture and animal domestication

formulas.title: Population Growth
formulas.formula: Population Growth Rate = (Births - Deaths) + (Immigration - Emigration)
formulas.explanation: Shows how human populations changed with the advent of agriculture

realworld.title: Archaeology
realworld.description: Modern methods like ground-penetrating radar help uncover ancient settlements

notes.title: Social Organization
points: From nomadic bands to settled communities

notes.title: Technological Progress
points: From stone to metal tools (Copper, Bronze, Iron Ages)

formulas.title: Cultural Development Index
formulas.formula: CDI = (Education + Technology + Social Organization) / 3
formulas.explanation: Measures the level of cultural development in early societies

realworld.title: Modern Society
realworld.description: Preservation of ancient sites and traditions helps us understand human development

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: Studying human evolution helps us understand our shared heritage and cultural diversity

notes.title: Overview
points: Flourished around 2600-1900 BCE in present-day Pakistan and northwest India
Major cities: Mohenjo-Daro, Harappa, Dholavira, Rakhigarhi
Advanced urban planning with grid system and drainage

notes.title: Achievements
points: Trade with Mesopotamia and other regions

formulas.title: Urban Planning Ratio
formulas.formula: City Area : Residential Area : Public Space ≈ 1 : 0.7 : 0.3
formulas.explanation: Shows the planned distribution of space in Indus cities

realworld.title: Modern Urban Planning
realworld.description: Ancient Indus drainage systems inspire modern sanitation solutions

notes.title: Overview
points: Developed along the Nile River (3100-332 BCE)
Known for pyramids, pharaohs, and mummification

formulas.title: Pyramid Construction
formulas.formula: Volume = (Base Area × Height) / 3
formulas.explanation: Formula used in pyramid construction, showing advanced mathematical knowledge

realworld.title: Modern Architecture
realworld.description: Egyptian engineering principles influence modern large-scale construction

notes.title: Overview
points: Between Tigris and Euphrates rivers (3500-500 BCE)
Cradle of civilization with first cities (Ur, Uruk, Babylon)

formulas.title: Cuneiform Tablet Production
formulas.formula: Tablet Size (cm²) ≈ Content Complexity × 2 + 10
formulas.explanation: Relationship between tablet size and content complexity in cuneiform writing

realworld.title: Modern Law
realworld.description: Hammurabi's Code influences modern legal principles of justice and evidence

notes.title: Definition and Importance
points: Supreme law of the land that defines the political principles, structure, and powers of government
Establishes the relationship between the government and citizens
Provides framework for governance and protects citizens' rights
Indian Constitution is the world's longest written constitution

formulas.title: Constitutional Framework
formulas.formula: Constitution = Preamble + Parts + Schedules + Amendments
formulas.explanation: Structure of the Indian Constitution with its key components

realworld.title: Democratic Governance
realworld.description: Forms the basis for all laws and governance in the country

notes.title: Significance
points: Protect individual liberties against state action
Not absolute - subject to reasonable restrictions
Can be suspended during emergency (except Articles 20-21)

formulas.title: Right to Equality
formulas.formula: Equality = Equal Protection + No Discrimination + Equal Opportunity
formulas.explanation: Core components of the Right to Equality

realworld.title: Social Justice
realworld.description: Allows citizens to approach courts for enforcement of fundamental rights

notes.title: Fundamental Duties (Article 51A)
points: To abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions
To cherish and follow noble ideals of freedom struggle
To uphold and protect sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
To defend the country and render national service when called upon
To promote harmony and spirit of common brotherhood

notes.title: Additional Duties
points: To protect and improve natural environment
To develop scientific temper and spirit of inquiry
To strive for excellence in all spheres

formulas.title: Duty Fulfillment Index
formulas.formula: DFI = (Duties Fulfilled / Total Duties) × 100
formulas.explanation: Measures the extent to which citizens fulfill their constitutional duties

realworld.title: Civic Responsibility
realworld.description: Example of citizens fulfilling their duty to maintain cleanliness and protect the environment

realworld.title: National Integration
realworld.description: Initiative promoting national unity and cultural exchange among states

notes.title: Definition and Purpose
points: A constitution is the supreme law of a country
It defines the structure of government and its organs
Establishes the relationship between the government and citizens
Provides a framework for governance and rule of law

notes.title: Salient Features of Indian Constitution
points: Longest written constitution in the world

formulas.title: Constitutional Amendment Process
formulas.formula: Amendment = (Proposal + Special Majority) + (Ratification by States if required)
formulas.explanation: The process to amend the Indian Constitution requires special majority in Parliament and in some cases, ratification by state legislatures

realworld.title: Constitutional Governance
realworld.description: The Indian Constitution ensures that all citizens, including government officials, are subject to and accountable under the law

notes.title: Significance
points: Protect individual liberties against state action
Justiciable - can be enforced in courts
Not absolute - subject to reasonable restrictions
Can be suspended during National Emergency (except Articles 20-21)

formulas.title: Writ Jurisdiction
formulas.formula: Habeas Corpus + Mandamus + Prohibition + Certiorari + Quo Warranto = Complete Protection
formulas.explanation: The five types of writs available under Article 32 for enforcement of Fundamental Rights

realworld.title: Landmark Judgments
realworld.description: Established the 'Basic Structure Doctrine' that Parliament cannot alter the basic structure of the Constitution

notes.title: Fundamental Duties (Article 51A)
points: To abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions
To cherish and follow the noble ideals of the freedom struggle
To uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
To defend the country and render national service when called upon
To promote harmony and spirit of common brotherhood

notes.title: Significance of Duties
points: Added by 42nd Amendment (1976) on recommendation of Swaran Singh Committee
Remind citizens of their responsibilities while enjoying rights
Help in promoting a sense of discipline and commitment
Strengthen democratic processes and national integration

formulas.title: Rights-Duties Relationship
formulas.formula: Rights + Duties = Responsible Citizenship
formulas.explanation: Fundamental Rights and Duties are two sides of the same coin - one cannot exist without the other in a democracy

realworld.title: Civic Engagement
realworld.description: A practical example of citizens fulfilling their fundamental duty to protect and improve the natural environment

realworld.title: National Integration
realworld.description: Reflects the duty to promote harmony and spirit of common brotherhood among all Indians

notes.title: Land
points: Characteristics: Fixed supply, immobile, differs in fertility

formulas.title: Production Function
formulas.formula:
Q = f(L, K, N, E)
where:
Q = Quantity of output
L = Labor
K = Capital
N = Land
E = Entrepreneurship
formulas.explanation: Shows relationship between inputs and outputs in production

realworld.title: Business
realworld.description: How factors of production come together in new business ventures

notes.title: Primary Sector
points: Contribution to GDP in developing countries

notes.title: Tertiary Sector
points: Largest contributor to GDP in developed nations

formulas.title: Employment Rate
formulas.formula: Employment Rate = (Employed People / Total Labor Force) × 100
formulas.explanation: Percentage of working-age population that is employed

realworld.title: Economic Development
realworld.description: Shift from primary to tertiary sector employment as economies develop

notes.title: Types of Unemployment
points: Seasonal: Due to seasonal nature of work (e.g., farming)
Disguised: More people employed than needed
Structural: Mismatch of skills and job requirements
Technological: Job losses due to automation

notes.title: Causes and Effects
points: Effects: Poverty, social unrest, economic burden

notes.title: Government Measures
points: MGNREGA (Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act)

formulas.title: Unemployment Rate
formulas.formula: Unemployment Rate = (Number of Unemployed / Labor Force) × 100
formulas.explanation: Percentage of labor force that is jobless and seeking employment

realworld.title: Government Policy
realworld.description: Initiative to boost manufacturing and create employment opportunities

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: Program to enhance employability through skill development

notes.title: Major Dynasties
points: Slave Dynasty (1206-1290): Founded by Qutb-ud-din Aibak
Khilji Dynasty (1290-1320): Notable ruler Alauddin Khilji
Tughlaq Dynasty (1320-1414): Muhammad bin Tughlaq's administrative experiments
Sayyid and Lodi Dynasties (1414-1526): Last of the Delhi Sultans

notes.title: Administration
points: Centralized administration with Sultan as supreme authority

formulas.title: Revenue Collection
formulas.formula: Land Revenue = (Total Agricultural Output - Cost of Cultivation) × Tax Rate
formulas.explanation: Basic structure of revenue collection during Delhi Sultanate

realworld.title: Urban Development
realworld.description: Example of Indo-Islamic architecture from the Delhi Sultanate period

notes.title: Great Mughals
points: Babur (1526-1530): Founded Mughal Empire, First Battle of Panipat (1526)
Akbar (1556-1605): Religious tolerance, Din-i-Ilahi, Mansabdari system
Shah Jahan (1628-1658): Golden Age of architecture, Taj Mahal
Aurangzeb (1658-1707): Expansion to Deccan, religious policies

notes.title: Administration
points: Mansabdari system: Military and civil administration
Zabt system: Revenue system under Akbar
Subas: Provinces divided into sarkars and parganas

formulas.title: Mansab Rank Calculation
formulas.formula:
Zat (Personal Rank) × 10 = Sawar (Cavalrymen)
Dagh (Branding) + Chehra (Descriptive Roll) = Army Organization
formulas.explanation: Military-administrative system under the Mughals

realworld.title: Cultural Heritage
realworld.description: Influence seen in modern Indian architecture and urban planning

notes.title: Administrative Structure
points: Centralized administration with king/emperor at the top
Wazir: Prime Minister, headed revenue and finance
Mir Bakshi: Head of military department

notes.title: Social Structure
points: Feudal system with kings, nobles, and peasants
Caste system continued but with some flexibility
Position of women: Purdah system, limited rights
Sufi and Bhakti movements influenced society

formulas.title: Revenue Assessment
formulas.formula: Land Revenue = (Total Land × Crop Yield × Government Share) - Remissions
formulas.explanation: Basic structure of land revenue assessment in medieval India

realworld.title: Governance
realworld.description: Lessons from medieval administration in modern governance

notes.title: Architecture
points: Indo-Islamic architecture: Blend of Indian and Persian styles
Key features: Arches, domes, minarets, calligraphy
Examples: Qutub Minar, Taj Mahal, Red Fort

notes.title: Literature and Music
points: Development of regional languages: Hindi, Bengali, Marathi

formulas.title: Architectural Ratio
formulas.formula: Dome Height : Minaret Height : Building Width ≈ 1 : 2 : 3
formulas.explanation: Common proportional relationships in Indo-Islamic architecture

realworld.title: Cultural Tourism
realworld.description: Many medieval Indian monuments are UNESCO World Heritage Sites

realworld.title: Performing Arts
realworld.description: Continuation of medieval musical traditions in modern Indian classical music

notes.title: Portuguese
points: Vasco da Gama arrived in Calicut (1498)
Established colonies in Goa, Daman, and Diu
Introduced new crops: Potato, tobacco, maize
Decline due to Dutch and British competition

notes.title: Dutch, French, and British
points: Dutch: Focused on spice trade from Southeast Asia
British: East India Company (1600), established Madras, Bombay, Calcutta
Carnatic Wars led to British dominance

formulas.title: Trade Monopoly
formulas.formula: Trade Power = (Naval Strength × Trading Posts) - Competition
formulas.explanation: Factors determining European dominance in Indian trade

realworld.title: Culinary Influence
realworld.description: Introduction of chili, potato, and bread to Indian cuisine

notes.title: Administrative Structure
points: Civil Services (ICS): Steel frame of British rule

notes.title: Economic Policies
points: Drain of Wealth theory by Dadabhai Naoroji

formulas.title: Drain of Wealth
formulas.formula: Drain = (Home Charges + Interest on Debt) - (Value of Services + Capital Inflow)
formulas.explanation: Calculation of economic drain from India to Britain

realworld.title: Civil Services
realworld.description: Modern successor to the ICS, continuing the administrative framework

notes.title: Reform Movements
points: Brahmo Samaj (Raja Ram Mohan Roy): Against Sati, for women's education
Arya Samaj (Dayanand Saraswati): Back to Vedas, against idol worship
Prarthana Samaj (Atmaram Pandurang): Social reform in Maharashtra
Aligarh Movement (Sir Syed Ahmed Khan): Modern education for Muslims

notes.title: Impact
points: Rise of modern Indian languages and literature

formulas.title: Reform Impact Index
formulas.formula: Impact = (Social Awareness + Legal Reforms + Education) / 3
formulas.explanation: Measuring the effectiveness of reform movements

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: Legacy of 19th century educational reforms

notes.title: Tribal Uprisings
points: Santhal Rebellion (1855-56): Against British land policies

notes.title: Peasant Movements
points: Indigo Revolt (1859-60): Against forced indigo cultivation

formulas.title: Resistance Strength
formulas.formula: Resistance = (Grievances × Organization) / Repression
formulas.explanation: Factors determining the intensity of resistance movements

realworld.title: Social Justice
realworld.description: Continuation of tribal rights movements in independent India

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Historical roots of contemporary farmers' issues

notes.title: Classification of Resources
points: Natural Resources: Air, water, soil, minerals
Human Resources: People and their skills

formulas.title: Resource Sustainability Index
formulas.formula: RSI = (Renewable Resources Used / Total Resources Used) × 100
formulas.explanation: Measures the sustainability of resource usage

realworld.title: Environmental Policy
realworld.description: Modern approach to sustainable resource use

notes.title: Land Resources
points: Total geographical area: 3.28 million sq km
Land use pattern: Net sown area, forests, wasteland
Major soil types: Alluvial, Black, Red, Laterite, Arid, Forest

notes.title: Water Resources
points: Major river systems: Ganga, Brahmaputra, Godavari, etc.

notes.title: Mineral and Energy Resources
points: Renewable energy potential: Solar, wind, hydro

formulas.title: Water Availability
formulas.formula: Per Capita Water Availability = Total Usable Water / Population
formulas.explanation: Measures water availability per person in cubic meters per year

realworld.title: Agriculture
realworld.description: Government initiative for sustainable soil management

notes.title: Individual Responsibility
points: Water and energy conservation at home
Use of public transport and carpooling

formulas.title: Ecological Footprint
formulas.formula: EF = (Carbon + Food + Housing + Goods + Services) / Earth's Capacity
formulas.explanation: Measures human demand on Earth's ecosystems

realworld.title: Urban Development
realworld.description: Integrating resource conservation in urban planning

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: Creating awareness about resource conservation in schools

notes.title: Key Components
points: Sovereign: India is an independent nation
Secular: No official religion, equal respect for all religions
Democratic: Government of the people, by the people, for the people
Republic: Head of state (President) is elected, not hereditary

notes.title: Significance
points: Source of authority: "We, the people of India..."
Contains objectives: Justice, Liberty, Equality, Fraternity
Reflects the basic structure of the Constitution

formulas.title: Preamble Analysis
formulas.formula: Preamble = Ideals + Objectives + Source of Authority
formulas.explanation: The Preamble combines the core ideals, objectives, and source of the Constitution's authority

realworld.title: Legal Interpretation
realworld.description: Preamble used by Supreme Court to interpret constitutional provisions

notes.title: Types of Fundamental Rights
points: Right to Equality (Articles 14-18): Equality before law, prohibition of discrimination
Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22): Freedom of speech, assembly, movement, etc.
Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24): Prohibition of human trafficking, child labor
Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28): Freedom of conscience and religion
Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30): Protection of minority interests
Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32): Right to approach Supreme Court

notes.title: Features
points: Justiciable: Can be enforced in courts
Not absolute: Subject to reasonable restrictions
Protection against state action, not private individuals

formulas.title: Right to Freedom Restrictions
formulas.formula: Freedom = Right - Reasonable Restrictions
formulas.explanation: Fundamental freedoms are subject to reasonable restrictions in public interest

realworld.title: Social Justice
realworld.description: Article 21A making education a fundamental right for children aged 6-14

notes.title: Nature and Importance
points: Aim to establish social and economic democracy
Based on Gandhian, Socialist, and Liberal principles

notes.title: Key Principles
points: Equal pay for equal work for men and women

formulas.title: DPSP Implementation
formulas.formula: DPSP + Political Will + Resources = Social Welfare
formulas.explanation: Implementation of Directive Principles requires political will and resources

realworld.title: Government Schemes
realworld.description: Implementation of right to work principle from DPSP

notes.title: List of Duties (Article 51A)
points: To abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals
To cherish and follow noble ideals of freedom struggle
To uphold and protect sovereignty, unity and integrity of India
To defend the country and render national service
To promote harmony and spirit of common brotherhood
To protect and improve natural environment
To develop scientific temper and spirit of inquiry
To strive for excellence in all spheres

notes.title: Significance
points: Help in maintaining discipline and national unity
Judicial interpretations have given them importance

formulas.title: Duty Fulfillment Index
formulas.formula: DFI = (Duties Practiced / Total Duties) × 100
formulas.explanation: Measures the extent to which citizens fulfill their fundamental duties

realworld.title: Civic Responsibility
realworld.description: Reflects the fundamental duty to maintain cleanliness

realworld.title: Education
realworld.description: Schools incorporating fundamental duties in curriculum

notes.title: Fundamental Concepts
points: Scarcity and Choice: Limited resources vs unlimited wants
Opportunity Cost: Cost of next best alternative foregone
Production Possibility Curve (PPC): Shows maximum production possibilities
Types of Goods: Consumer goods, capital goods, public goods

notes.title: Economic Systems
points: Capitalist Economy: Private ownership, profit motive
Socialist Economy: State ownership, welfare motive
Mixed Economy: Coexistence of public and private sectors (India's model)

formulas.title: Opportunity Cost
formulas.formula: Opportunity Cost = Return of Best Foregone Option - Return of Chosen Option
formulas.explanation: Calculates the cost of choosing one option over another

realworld.title: Economic Planning
realworld.description: India's approach to economic development through planned investments

notes.title: Primary Sector
points: Challenges: Low productivity, dependence on monsoons

formulas.title: Sectoral Contribution
formulas.formula: Sector's % in GDP = (Sector's GVA / Total GVA) × 100
formulas.explanation: Calculates a sector's contribution to Gross Value Added (GVA)

realworld.title: Employment
realworld.description: Rise of platform-based work in service sector

topics.name: Role of Government in Economic Development

notes.title: Economic Functions
points: Provision of public goods: Defense, law and order
Redistribution of income: Progressive taxation, subsidies
Economic stability: Monetary and fiscal policies
Regulation and control: Preventing monopolies, consumer protection

notes.title: Development Initiatives
points: Infrastructure development: Roads, ports, digital India
Skill development: PMKVY, National Skill Development Mission

formulas.title: Fiscal Multiplier
formulas.formula:
Fiscal Multiplier = 1 / (1 - MPC)
where MPC = Marginal Propensity to Consume
formulas.explanation: Measures the effect of government spending on national income

realworld.title: Digital India
realworld.description: Jan Dhan, Aadhaar, Mobile - Government's financial inclusion initiative

realworld.title: Infrastructure
realworld.description: Flagship programs for road and port connectivity
